title: What happens when a CEO gets impostor syndrome? - Quora

response.answer_text: The strengths of a CEO and the strengths of a psychopath are not very different. The “Fake It ’til You Make It” ethic in Silicon Valley inspires all kinds of chicanery. IIRC an incident was reported in the book “The Soul of the New Machine” wherein a computer company brought a great big computer to a trade show — big enough so that a small man with a small computer could hide inside and type out human responses to simulate what the big computer was represented as doing. Academics are famous for suffering imposter syndrome. The celebrated writer Joan Didion discussed it in one of her essays. I wish I could remember the language. Something about all the lucky breaks, and the mistakes no one noticed. Successful CEOs have the advantage over academics because they can point at the money they’re bringing in. “Wall Street thinks I’m real, and therefore I must be real,” can be a powerful syllogism for a self-doubting CEO. In extreme cases, you get an Elizabeth Holmes who, after justifying her lies as part of a beautiful quest, perhaps even comes to believe them. I’ve written quite a bit about the 9/11 Keymaster, who traveled the world appearing on TV and collecting money and getting photographed with movie stars and heads of state on the basis of a fabricated hero story. I’ve seen him, but I never met him. I can’t pretend to know his mind. But it’s hard to escape the suspicion that when he told a hall full of cheering admirers that he was hero, he started to believe it himself. How could so many people be wrong?

He already had imposter syndrome before he became CEO. Imposter syndrome doesn't mean he is not qualified. It means he doesn't know what he should be or if he is in the right field. He didn't fake his way to the position. He's not sure if he is where he should be.
